docs.lead_paragraph: The death of two-month-old Tyler Walrond from malnutrition in 1997 has been made more tragic by the prosecution of his mother, Tabitha Walrond, who goes on trial in the Bronx for manslaughter tomorrow. If convicted, she could face up to 15 years in prison. Ms. Walrond, who breast-fed her son, is charged with recklessly causing her baby's death by failing to feed him sufficiently and to seek medical care when he became sickly. No other signs of abuse were found. One can sympathize with Tyler's father, who has urged prosecutors to go forward in the belief that Ms. Walrond was reckless in not heeding obvious signs that the baby was starving. But expert testimony on how difficult it is for many nursing mothers to recognize the danger signs by themselves and evidence that the medical system let this young woman down suggest that this is not a case that should be prosecuted.
docs.abstract: Editorial questions wisdom of trying Tabitha Walrond for manslaughter in starvation death of her infant, whom she was breast-feeding; sympathizes with infant's father, who urged prosecution in belief that Walrond was reckless in not heeding obvious signs that baby was starving, but says prison would be inappropriate for tragedy that arose from ignorance
docs.snippet: The death of two-month-old Tyler Walrond from malnutrition in 1997 has been made more tragic by the prosecution of his mother, Tabitha Walrond, who goes on trial in the Bronx for manslaughter tomorrow. If convicted, she could face up to 15 years in...

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of a bipartisan commission studying the future of Medicare made a last-ditch effort tonight to salvage his proposal for radical changes in the health insurance program for the elderly, but he said he did not know if he could round up the necessary votes in time for the panel's final meeting on Tuesday. Moreover, the chairman, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said President Clinton had given him no assistance in trying to get those votes. Mr. Breaux needs support from at least one of the President's four appointees on the 17-member commission, but Mr. Breaux said he had not secured support from any of them.

headline.main: Medicare Panel Chief Doubts He'll Find Votes for Change

docs.abstract: Sen John B Breaux, chairman of bipartisan commission studying future of Medicare, makes last-ditch effort to salvage his proposal for radical changes in health insurance program for elderly; says he does not know if he can round up necessary votes in time for panel's final meeting on March 16; says Pres Clinton has given him no assistance in trying to get votes (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Consider it the ultimate play in celebrity marketing. A new Web site bearing the name of Dr. C. Everett Koop, who as United States Surgeon General during the Reagan Administration became America's doctor, is about to join the ranks of Internet initial public offerings. Forget that drkoop.com, which offers free medical information, has been up and running for only nine months and last year had revenues of only $48,000. The association with the outspoken Dr. Koop is what the venture's founders are clearly banking on. The company, which calls its site ''Your Trusted Health Network,'' will go public under the Nasdaq symbol KOOP.

headline.main: From Celebrity Doctor, Medical Advice on Line

docs.abstract: Your Trusted Health Network, whose Web site bears name of Dr C Everett Koop, former US Surgeon General, will seek to raise $50 million through initial public offering; drkoop.com offers free medical information, discussion groups, support groups and information on insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Tabitha Walrond, a 19-year-old welfare recipient, gave birth to her first child on June 27, 1997, she did what new mothers rich and poor are urged to do these days: she breast-fed her baby. But on Aug. 27, seven weeks after leaving the hospital, the son she had named Tyler Isaac Walrond died in her arms of malnutrition. Ms. Walrond goes on trial Tuesday in the Bronx, charged with recklessly causing Tyler's death by failing to nourish him adequately and by failing to obtain prompt medical attention when his condition became dire.

headline.main: Placing the Blame in an Infant's Death; Mother Faces Trial After Baby Dies From Lack of Breast Milk

docs.abstract: Trial of Tabitha Walrond, charged with recklessly causing her infant son Tyler's death fron malnutrition by failing to nourish him adequately and by failing to obtain prompt medical attention when his condition became dire, to begin this week in Bronx; advocates for women and poor contend that Tyler's death was not a crime, but tragedy that reflects hidden perils of breast-feeding and obstacles to health care for poor children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bumped off an overbooked flight home hours earlier, Jim Mihnovich stood at the end of a long line at Long Island MacArthur Airport this morning a grateful man. Grateful mostly for Southwest Airlines, which started operations at MacArthur today. ''This was awesome,'' he said, pocketing one of the carrier's distinctive blue plastic boarding passes for a 12:10 P.M. flight to Nashville.

headline.main: Southwest Flights at MacArthur Take Off to Mixed Reactions

docs.abstract: Southwest Airlines begins service from Long Island MacArthur Airport in Islip, NY; airline initially will offer 12 nonstops a day with plans to schedule more flights if interest warrants it; concern by local residents over noise and real estate value discussed (M)
